Prepared by Joseph Vance
Revised by Jeffery Bryson

controlnote.p: Converted to EAD3 : Encoded Archival Description (EAD), Version 3 : Release: 1.1.1 : Release Date: 2019-12-16. Validating against latest version of schema.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Converted from EAD 2002 to EAD 3 (Release 1.1.1) by ead3_converter_mfer.xsl : Michael Ferrando, Library of Congress.
Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Biographer, editor, educator, and lecturer. Correspondence, diaries, manuscripts and proofs of books and other works, articles, speeches, notebooks, source materials largely relating to the American Revolution and Civil War, bibliographical material, clippings, printed material, memorabilia, maps, photographs, and other papers relating primarily to Freeman's biographical and historical research and writing.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Freeman, Douglas Southall, 1886-1953. George Washington: a biography. 1948-1957.
Freeman, Douglas Southall, 1886-1953. Lee's lieutenants: a study in command. 1946.
Freeman, Douglas Southall, 1886-1953. R.E. Lee: a biography. 1934-1935.
Freeman, Douglas Southall, 1886-1953. South to posterity: an introduction to the writings of Confederate history. 1939.

geogname.part: United States--Social life and customs--20th century.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Douglas Southall Freeman, biographer, editor, teacher, and lecturer, were given to the Library of Congress by his wife, Inez Freeman, in 1955.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed in 1957. The finding aid was revised in 2013.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Guides
otherfindaid.p:
A press release on the Douglas Southall Freeman papers was issued by the Library of Congress on Aug. 22, 1955; an acquisitions note on them appeared in the Library's
Information Bulletin 14, no. 33 (August 15, 1955): 3-4; and they were described in the
Library of Congress Quarterly Journal of Current Acquisitions 13, no. 3 (May 1956): 156. In 1960 the Library published
Douglas Southall Freeman, a Register of His Papers in the Library of Congress .

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Douglas Southall Freeman is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Douglas Southall Freeman are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Douglas Southall Freeman Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Ph.D., Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.
Commissioned by Scribner's Sons to write biography of Robert E. Lee

Published
R. E. Lee: A Biography . New York: Scribner's. 4 vols.

chronitemset.event: Rector and president, Board of Trustees of the University of Richmond, Richmond, Va.

chronitem.event: Taught journalism, Columbia University, New York, N.Y.

Published
The South to Posterity; An Introduction to the Writings of Confederate History . New York: Scribner's

Published
Lee's Lieutenants: A Study in Command . New York: Scribner's. 3 vols.

Published
George Washington, a Biography . New York: Scribner's. 7 vols. (vol. 7 by John A. Carroll and Mary W. Ashworth)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Significant in the collection are transcripts, photostats, maps, and source material that Freeman used in the writing of his books. Notes and bibliographies are also included. Newspaper clippings, photographs, printed matter, programs, and other memorabilia complete the collection.

The papers reveal an extensive correspondence between Freeman and prominent historians, literary figures, politicians, educators, and military leaders including Frederic William Boatwright, Harry Flood Byrd, Colgate W. Darden, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Ellen Anderson Gholson Glasgow, Dumas Malone, George C. Marshall, Allan Nevins, A. Willis Robertson, and Harry S. Truman. In addition there is business, professional, and social correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in nine series:

item.ref: Material Relating to the Death of Freeman, 1953-1954

scopecontent.p: Diaries, and journals of trips with related correspondence, notes, drafts of articles, and photographs.

arrangement.p: Arranged by type of material and therein chronologically.

Arranged chronologically by periods of one or several years with alphabetical arrangement by name of correspondent or subject within a given period. These are Freeman's working files essentially as he used them. Strict chronology is not always followed; for example, the Library of Congress file for 1951 has material for several years within it.
